Jewish Labor Committee Records, Part III

The Anti-Discrimination Department was formed during World War II and contributed greatly to the eventual creation of a similar department in the American Federation of Labor. The topical files are arranged alphabetically within each year (as originally filed by the JLC) and include material on civil rights issues, discrimination in employment, and anti-Semitism. The documents reflect the Anti-Discrimination Department's work with local Community Relations Councils, the National Community Relations Advisory Council, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP), and other national Jewish and/or civil rights groups. Of particular note is the group of files documenting the JLC's well-known survey of race relations in labor unions in the South, carried out by National Director Emanuel Muravchik beginning in 1956.
